PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may have been in any province that has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preparation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

May 1, 1955
1. Your full name: Mrs. Clara M. Rusk

2. Your address: 724 Rusk Avenue, B.C.

3. Date: July 24, 1957

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Minneapolis, Minnesota, U.S.A.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? John Rusk, farmer.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May 4, 1903.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: only in Minnesota.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.): 13 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? My mother and brother got homessteads to getter and build up a good home.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): From other friends in Minnesota, some of them took up homesteads in the Yellow Grass District.
1. Your full name: Mrs. Clara M. Rusk

2. Your address: 217 A, Maplelea Drive, Edmonton, Alta.

3. Date: July 18, 1957

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Woodhead, Prince Edward Island

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: John Thornton, farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May 4, 1903

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan:

   - Prince Edward Island
   - New Brunswick
   - Nova Scotia
   - Ontario

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 13 years old

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: My mother and brother got homesteads together and built up a good home.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Minnesota, some of them took up homesteads in the Yellow Grass District.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Some thought it was a good idea, and some didn't.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)? I traveled with my mother, and my brother came with me.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) It was my first train ride, so I found it very interesting. We changed trains in Winnipeg, and thought it was a nice city with its wide streets.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Bowbells.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? 14 mi. West of Bowbells, now called Shaunavon District.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. As I mentioned before, I moved after living on Stonecreek, 48 years.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came? Farming, always farming.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   several times a year.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the
    date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? It as a
    place to settle? The Homesteaders were all taken up by
    ourselves, so we couldn't tell anyone about land.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West
    tell when they came and where they settled.

My Brother John Knudsen, and Christine Knudsen came
about May 4, 1903. Their Home stand was 3 mi. North of Skarns.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your
    memory which you would like to recount?

We enjoyed pioneering only the first situation
was bad, we could not buy wood or decent coal,
had to burn green poplar poles which we got from
the Nut Hill, about 9 miles away.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business attending
    church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of
    travel?

We drove a team, on the buggy, to visit
old friends near Yellow Grass, once a trip buying
out here 3 or 4 years, the drive was about 75 miles.

We enjoyed pioneering only the first winter we were here. We could not buy wood or decent coal. Had to burn green poplar poles which we got from the Blue Hills about 9 miles away.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1927? What reasons did they have for moving?

Quite a few moved back to the state mainly Montana, but some of their families stayed in Jack.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Some went up North, most of the people around Breivicht stayed.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates whenever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, building, organizing the first lodge, etc.). I am quite sure we had the first Combine, namely Holt, got it in 1927, and it's still in good condition, Captain Chas Jagues also first of the farmers to own an auto.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (school districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Pla Captain Jagues gave the name of Breivicht.

P.O. he saw some land grading, near the old site where the C.M.R. came she said work at the Briar, when the C.M.R. came there in 1912, the town took the name of the Breivicht, P.O.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1927? What reasons did they have for moving?

Quite a few moved back to the States, mainly Montana, but some of their families stayed in South Dakota.

35. Did many people leave during the 1930s? Did many return?

Some went up North, most of the people around Brevard stayed.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "flirtin' to have or do some-thing" in the district mention it here giving date whenever possible.

Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.

I am quite sure we had the first Combic, mainly Holt. Got it in 1927 and it is still in good condition. Captain Chas Jacques was first of the farmers to own an auto.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (school districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggested; (2) any changes in names since the first name was given; (3) date of first name. For change, give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The Captain Jacques, gave the name of Brevard. As he saw some land grading, on a hillside she said look at the Brainy where the C.M.R. came through in 1912. The town took the name of the place.
